FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 179 B 1900

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
AND PINAR DEL RIO.
Quemados, Cuba, June 22, 1900.

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 43. }
Stark - Kean - Hepburn

1. Private Charles Oakley, Troop K, 7th Cavalry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Columbia
Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of drunkenness on duty,
in violation of the 38th Article of War, was sentenced “To
be confined at hard labor, under charge of the post guard, for four
(4) months, and to forfeit ten (10) dollars per month for the same
period.”
The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed.

2. Private Gregor G. Krein, Company E. 8th Infantry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, charged with absence without
leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War, was acquitted.

The acquittal is approved. Private Krein will be released
from confinement and restored to duty.

3. Private William Brower, Company G, 8th Infantry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of absence from
11 P. M. inspection, in violation of the 33d Article of War;
and conduct to the prejudice of good order and military
discipline (six previous convictions), was sentenced “To
be dishonorably discharged the service of the United States, for-
feiting all pay and allowances due him, and to be confined at hard
labor, under charge of the post guard, for three (3) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

4. Captain A. N. Stark, Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army,
is announced as Acting Chief Surgeon of the Department
during the illness of Major J. R. Kean, Chief Surgeon.

In addition to his duties as Acting Chief Surgeon, he is
announced as Acting Chief Sanitary Officer, and Superin-
tendent of Charities and Hospitals for the duties required
by paragraph 2, General Orders No. 14, series 1899, and
paragraph 4, General Orders No. 1, series 1900, Headquar-
ters Department of the Province of Havana and Pinar del
Rio.

5. 2d Lieutenant C. R. Day, 7th Cavalry, Aid, is an-
nounced as Acting Signal Officer of the Department during
the illness of Captain C. B. Hepburn, Department Signal
Officer.

6. 2d Lieutenant C. R. Day, 7th Cavalry, is announced
as commanding the detachment of enlisted men on duty at
these headquarters.

Lieutenant Day will take the necessary action towards
providing camp accommodations for this detachment.

7. Private Jessie Thurston, Troop B, 7th Cavalry; Frank
Englehart, Troop F, 7th Cavalry; and Edward Becker, Troop
B, 7th Cavalry, are hereby detailed on special duty as mes-
sengers at these headquarters.

Under the provisions of A. R. 1272, the Subsistence De-
partment will commute the rations of the above named en-
listed men, whilst they are engaged on this duty, at the
rate of seventy-five (75) cents per day, it being impracti-
cable to provide for their subsistence in any other way.

8. Private John L. Doyle, Company B, 8th Infantry, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at Co-
lumbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of neglect of duty,
to the prejudice of good order and military discipline; and
drunkenness on duty, in violation of the 38th Article of
War (five previous convictions), was sentenced “To be dis-
honorably discharged the service of the United States, forfeiting
all pay and allowances due him, and to be confined at hard labor,
under charge of the post guard, for three (3) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

9. Private James Green, Light Battery F, 2d Artillery,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of leaving post,
in violation of the 39th Article of War (three previous con-
victions), was sentenced “To forfeit ten (10) dollars per
month of his pay, for the period of six (6) months.”
The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed.

10. Until further orders, such mounted sentinels as may
be necessary from the Rural Guard will be posted in the
town of Quemados. These sentinels will be required to
patrol all streets in this town.

All soldiers and civilian employees found therein, unless
engaged in work under orders of the Sanitary Officer, will
be arrested and conducted to the Military Provost Guard
Camp just beyond the Quemados Railroad Station, and
there turned over to that guard. All soldiers and civilian
